meanings.definition: To bury or embed in the earth.
meanings.sent1: The squirrel decided to inearth its acorn for safekeeping.
meanings.sent2: Farmers often inearth seeds to help them grow into plants.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous dog tried to inearth its bone in the flower bed.
meanings.sent4: She chose to inearth her memories deep within her heart.
meanings.sent5: The ancient civilization would inearth their treasures to protect them from thieves.

meanings.definition: To cover or hide in the ground.
meanings.sent1: The archaeologists carefully inearthed the ancient artifacts for preservation.
meanings.sent2: Children love to inearth their treasures in secret spots in the backyard.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick was to inearth the coin and make it disappear.
meanings.sent4: The storm threatened to inearth the small town under layers of snow.
meanings.sent5: The old tree roots seemed to inearth the pathway, making it hard to walk.

meanings.definition: To establish or set firmly in the ground.
meanings.sent1: The gardener wanted to inearth the new plant to ensure its growth.
meanings.sent2: The construction workers needed to inearth the poles deep into the soil.
meanings.sent3: The idea of friendship was inearthed in their hearts since childhood.
meanings.sent4: The tradition of family values was inearthed in their culture for generations.
meanings.sent5: The foundation of the building was inearthed with strong concrete pillars.
